newsitem.title: INDIA: India debates parliament quota for women.
newsitem.headline: India debates parliament quota for women.

text.p: Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda on Thursday introduced a bill in parliament to reserve 33 percent of seats in the lower house of parliament and the state assemblies for women.
The bill, favoured by major political parties, would require an amendment to the constitution by a two-thirds majority in parliament before becoming law.
Deve Gowda committed himself to providing reserved seats for women in his Independence Day address to the nation on August 15.
Women deputies said they wanted the parliament to settle the matter on Thursday itself.
In response, lower house Speaker Purno Sangma departed from normal procedures and suspended the daily question hour to allow the bill's introduction.
Only seven percent of the 545 members of parliament are women.
The Indian parliament and state assemblies earmark certain electoral constituencies for low caste Hindus and tribespeople.
The new bill is expected to create constituencies from which only women can be elected.
